entry.title: Diary/01/31/16
entry.content:
回来也有两个星期了，昨天刷完了Neuroecnomics的课程，总分97.3%。因为简单所以也是预料之中。
然而回来到现在却也感觉没学到什么东西，Medical Neuroscience的Quiz也一个都没刷，今天一看视频也是困意频频来袭，想写点什么又觉得没什么可说的，但总是要写些什么的吧。

最近感觉三观有有了一点点的改变，按照普世的观点应该是好的吧，虽然目前为止还没有在行动上有所体现。但我现在越来越期望一个有着良好学习状态的自己了，而我相信这一天也快来到了。

说说自己的观念哪里变了：

1、对于某理论是用于解释问题还是加以运用。以前是倾向于通过某理论解释问题，然而却很少想根据这个理论我能做出什么改变。从今往后我想我都要加入这个几乎没有被考虑到的因素了。

2、对Follow your heart这句话的理解。前一阵其实已经有点完全任由潜意识来主宰自己了，有点失去了作为理性个体本身所拥有的控制能力。遵从subconscious可以解决一些问题这个我不反对，问题是它本身所固有的属性很多都是我们平时所说的堕落方面的，并不能带来问题的最优解（其实作为人本身也许根本就没有问题的最优解，只有在所拥有的资源下寻找最好的方案）。而我所做的其实是平衡好理性与非理性之间的冲突，提升自我的效率。其实应该以前也是这样做的，但不知道为什么最近却忘记了这方面的探索。也许是对自我很少能真正决定自己的决策行为所感到的悲观以至于放弃自己了吧。 其实，我能做的还有很多，对吧？

所以感觉最近要改改半夜两三点睡的习惯了，回来半个月了，黑眼圈一直都没有消掉。再这样感觉真的要挂掉了…

然后，今天晚歇醒来的一瞬间又重新体验了回对死亡、对虚无的恐惧。中学时候的老毛病了，上大学很少有了。不过也有点好处，能惊醒自己，以防自己就这么一步一步堕落下去。而且吧，今天还想了下出现这种情况的生理学机制，目前认为是醒来的短时间内大脑不同区域的激活成都不同所导致，具体是哪还无从得知。不过这次给了我一点学药学神经学的动力，毕竟每周15+小时的课不是说着玩的，这次要是真能好好跟着学完了收获一定很大的。

最近看知乎这个问题——>人类有什么细思极恐的细节？的时候发现好多问题之前自己都想过，里面对好多问题的见解都跟以前不一样的。这大概就是我上大学以来真正进步的地方吧，不再跟随问题提出者的思维方式。希望这不要成为我以后理解问题的阻碍。

最后，贴 证 书~(≧▽≦)/~

entry.title: Diary 10/23/15
entry.content:
Yesterday, I read a book about “face” –《看脸》. I’d like to make a summary of the book later.
And I read a article about consciousness&vision this morning – What are we talking about when we say “consciousness”
Click–>我们说『意识』的时候，我们在说些什么?
This article mainly said that it’s difficult for us to measure consciousness and why difficult?
I made a parallelism sentence after reading this article:
你以为你说出来的这句话，其实也许并不是他们听到的那句话。（基于对词汇认知的偏差）
你以为你披在外面的这张脸，其实也不是别人看到的那张脸。（基于人脸的不对称和个人看镜子与他人看你脸的方向是左右相反的）
你以为你看到的这世间万物，其实也并不是别人看到的那世界。（基于人的认知只是客观世界的一小部分）

I saw the movie 《业火的向日葵》today after class, which is another theatrical version about detective Conan.
Conan used to be my favorite animation when I was a junior school student,but I don’t fanatical in it anymore. Maybe it just because I can’t get anything touched me except some basic detective knowledge from this animation. It can’t make me think deep and inspired me. But when I saw the moive today,I can still remember every character in all details, waht he like or what she don’t like.
What you once cherish never dies in the river of time, though these things no longer exist in your life, probably.

I still have too many things todo recently, but sometime I just not sure where to start. (I think maybe that’s why I can’t do things well). Another problem is I can’t focus on one thing for a long time(30min or more), and I’am easily to think about the things that not relevant to the subject when I studying. But according to my perspection, some guys can!! We’re totally different kinds of people.o(╯□╰)o

Share a blog about neuro&brain.
Click–>Neuroscience for beginners V2.0
This blog serves as the notes repository for MOOC Neuroscience ventures which include notes about
the course SYNAPSES, NEURONS AND BRAIN. I just finished the course this month, and these notes helped me a lot.

I have lots of programming experiment to do in the following few weeks. I think I will spend much more time in study than before because of my poor programming skills. Most of time I just don’t know where to start. So I decide to read some books about how to design programs and review the basic knowledge about C/C++ language.

Here are some books&articles I find today:

How to design programs –MIT Press
The book introduces the concept of a design recipe, a six-step process for creating programs from the problem statement. While the book was originally used in conjunction with the TeachScheme! project (now ProgramByDesign), it has been adopted at a number of colleges and universities for the teaching of program design principles. –via Wikipedia
But I won’t read this book recently, because this is discussing about how to design programs using LISP language which different from C/C++/JAVA that I learned.

And another book(or notes?) is 《设计模式精解–GoF 23种设计模式解析 附C++实现源码》
This book is more useful to me now.

And I think I should pay more attention to oprate system&database princple. I just haven’t have chance to open these textbooks after class!

entry.title: Hebbian Learning
entry.content:
Introduce to a interesting website:
Neurotic Neurons
This website give us a simple and clear example of Hebbian Learning (a classical theory in nueroscience that propose by Donald Hebb in 1949), using a well designed interactive animation.

The most important concept I wanted to introduce here was exposure therapy, which is part of Cognitive Behavioral Therapy. CBT is basically being mindful of your crappy neural connections, and gaining skills to retrain those connections. –by author

Part of the subtitles:

//////////////
// MY FEARS //
//////////////

"fear0": "THIS is what happens.",
"fear1": "Innocent thoughts connect to anxious thoughts.",
"fear2": "Personally, I used to be so afraid of being seen as a failure,",
"fear3": "of being close to people,",
"fear4": "and of...",
"fear5": "holes.",
"fear6": "Coz... I don't know why, but tightly clustered holes",
"fear7": "just kinda creep me out, y'know? I dunno.",

//////////////////////
// HEBBIAN LEARNING //
//////////////////////

"hebb0": "[SOUNDS]",
"hebb1": "Anyway... how do we learn these fears in the first place?",
"hebb2": "Well, to explain that, let me get rid of all this...",
"hebb3": "and give you...",
"hebb4": "this!",

"hebb5": "Hebbian Learning.",
"hebb6": "“Neurons that fire together, wire together.”",

"hebb7": "This is a rule of thumb that neuroscientists use to describe how",
"hebb8": "neurons make new connections.",
"hebb9": "Basically, if you fire one neuron, then fire another neuron,",
"hebb10": "the first neuron will connect TO the second neuron.",
"hebb11": "Try it out for yourself!",

"hebb12": "Too slow! You didn't click fast enough. Try again?",
"hebb13": "Not close enough. Try a different pair of neurons.",

"hebb14": "And that's how we learn!",
"hebb15": "Of course, we don't learn that quickly in real life,",
"hebb16": "I sped this simulation up, eh, but still.",
"hebb17": "Now play around, make a few more connections,",
"hebb18": "maybe make a chain or something.",

"hebb19": "This learning rule is why, if you were bitten by a dog as a kid,",
"hebb20": "you might develop a fear of dogs!",
"hebb21": "Because your 'dog' neuron fired, then your 'pain' neuron fired.",
"hebb22": "And thus, 'dog' connected to 'pain'.",

///////////////////////////
// ANTI-HEBBIAN LEARNING //
///////////////////////////

"anti0": "Anyway, if that's how we learn, here's how we un-learn.",

"anti1": "Anti-Hebbian Learning.",
"anti2": "“Neurons that fire out of sync, lose their link.”",

"anti3": "Another rule of thumb neuroscientists have!",

"anti4": "So - if you already have a connection from one neuron to another,",
"anti5": "and you fire the first neuron WITHOUT firing the second neuron,",
"anti6": "the connection weakens.",
"anti7": "Again, try it out.",

"anti8": "That neuron didn't have any connections.",
"anti9": "You need to find one that's connected.",
"anti10": "Ah, so that neuron only has connections going TO it, but not FROM it.",
"anti11": "You need to find one that has connections FROM it.",

"anti12": "Now wait for it...",
"anti13": "And look! The connection's weaker.",
"anti14": "Do that again, and this time, the connection will be totally killed.",

"anti15": "And this unlearning rule is why, if you have a fear of dogs,",
"anti16": "and you're exposed to friendly dogs over and over again,",
"anti17": "you might unlearn that fear.",
"anti18": "'Dog' neuron gets fired, WITHOUT the 'pain' neuron getting fired,",
"anti19": "and therefore - the connection weakens.",

/////////////

"ther1": "...this.",

"ther2": "I want you to re-train this brain.",
"ther3": "Rewire, reconnect each of these three things,",
"ther4": "from feeling fear, to feeling safe.",

"ther5": "See, rewiring yourself may cause anxiety in the short term...",
"ther6": "...but it is SO worth it in the long term.",

"ther7": "One down, two more to go.",
